02_01: Proof by contradiction works by assuming the statement is false. If this leads to a logical contradiction, the original statement must be true. For example, to prove √2 is irrational, assume it's rational and show this is impossible.
02_02: The contrapositive of 'If n is even, then n^2 is even' is 'If n^2 is not even, then n is not even.' Contrapositives are always logically equivalent to the original statement.
02_03: The intersection A ∩ B is the set of elements in both A and B. Here, both sets share 2 and 3.
02_04: The symbol ∅ represents the empty set, which contains no elements.
02_05: The cardinality of a set is the number of elements it contains. P = {a, b, c} has 3 elements.
02_06: The power set of X = {1,2} is the set of all subsets: {}, {1}, {2}, and {1,2}.
02_07: The symbol ⊆ means 'is a subset of.' This means every element of one set is in the other.
02_08: The union of any set A with the empty set ∅ is just A. The empty set adds nothing.
02_09: The complement of the universal set U is the empty set ∅, since U contains everything.
02_10: {a, b} is a subset of {a, b, c} because every element in the smaller set is in the larger set.
02_11: A ∪ (B ∩ C) = (A ∪ B) ∩ (A ∪ C) is an example of the distributive law in set theory.
02_12: If A and B are disjoint, they share no elements. Their intersection is ∅.
02_13: x ∈ A means x is an element of set A (for example, 2 ∈ {1,2,3}).
02_14: Proof by contrapositive proves 'if not Q then not P' instead of 'if P then Q.' This method is logically equivalent.
02_15: Since 4 is an even number and A is the set of even numbers, 4 ∈ A is true.
02_16: The identity law for sets says A ∪ ∅ = A and A ∩ U = A. Adding the empty set or intersecting with everything doesn't change the set.
02_17: A set with n elements has 2^n subsets. For example, with 3 elements: {}, {a}, {b}, {c}, {a,b}, {a,c}, {b,c}, {a,b,c}.
02_18: A ∩ B' is the area inside A but outside B on a Venn diagram. It's all elements in A that are not in B.
02_19: To show A = B, you must prove A ⊆ B and B ⊆ A (that they contain exactly the same elements).
02_20: If A ⊆ B and B ⊆ C, then A ⊆ C. This is the transitive property for subsets.
02_21: Proof by contradiction means assuming the statement is false, showing this leads to an impossible situation, so the original must be true.
02_22: ∅ is the standard symbol for the empty set, which contains no elements.
02_23: A ⊆ B if and only if every element of A is also an element of B. Subset means 'all members of A are in B.'
02_24: The power set of {1, 2} includes all possible subsets: ∅, {1}, {2}, and {1,2}.
02_25: A set with 4 elements has 2^4 = 16 subsets.
02_26: Any set A is always a subset of itself (A ⊆ A).
02_27: {2, 4} is not a subset of {1, 2, 3} because 4 is not in A.
02_28: The union of any set A with the empty set ∅ is just A. The empty set doesn't add elements.
02_29: The intersection of any set A and the universal set U is A, since all elements of A are in U.
02_30: If A ⊆ B and B ⊆ C, then A ⊆ C. This is the transitive property for subsets.
02_31: A \ B is the set of elements in A but not in B.
02_32: DeMorgan's law for sets says (A ∪ B)' = A' ∩ B'.
02_33: The complement of the universal set U is the empty set ∅, because U contains everything.
02_34: Proof by contradiction assumes the opposite of what you want to prove, shows this leads to a contradiction, and therefore the original must be true.
02_35: A = {x ∈ N | x < 3} means all natural numbers less than 3, so A = {1, 2}.
02_36: The empty set is a subset of every set, because there is no element in ∅ that isn't in any other set.
02_37: If sets are disjoint, their intersection is empty: A ∩ B = ∅.
02_38: The cardinality of {1,2,3,4,5} is 5 because it contains 5 elements.
02_39: An existence proof shows something exists by providing an explicit example.
02_40: A ∩ B means the elements that are in both sets. Both sets contain 2 and 3, so A ∩ B = {2,3}.
